resources: FUGA POR MEXICO Open navigation drawer Close navigation drawer User sebas.rg07@gmail.com Navigation header Help Home Favorites Discounts of the day Mis Trips Photos // Password Email Login Register User register User Already have an account? // Explore Aguascalientes Aguascalientes Events Discover Aguascalientes San Marcos Garden Bullring San Marcos Fair Historic Center of Aguascalientes Main Square Aguascalientes Cathedral Cerro del Muerto Temple of San Antonio Island San Marcos Museum of Aguascalientes Restaurants Hotels Pubs Parking lot Sign off Delete account // Telephone: Horary: Attention: Tuesday/Sunday Web Call All the days Name: Go Promotions Scan your codes Scan // The first Aguascalientes fair was held in 1828. In its beginnings it was held in the month of November, giving rise to the Parián located in front of the San Diego Temple, which had exclusively commercial purposes. It changed to the month of April, within the celebrations of San Marcos, an old Indian town located a few blocks from the main square of the capital With the arrival of the railroad in 1884, the city strengthened its old vocation as merchants and, with it, its regional primacy, so that the fair could be promoted and known beyond the limits of a small town festival. Within the popular imagination, the coronation of the Queen (a tradition that began in the 1920s) represents not only a beauty contest but also the longing for a society, where the governor crowns the chosen one, the poet improvises the eulogy and the people admire the majesty of the act. The Cerro del Muerto is a mountainous massif, which is located in the municipalities of Aguascalientes and Jesús María, in the State of Aguascalientes in Mexico, it presents an oak forest in the upper parts and in some slopes and ravines. Calvillo Magical Town It received its appointment as a Magic Town in November 2012. Located in the state of Aguascalientes, it bears the name of Calvillo, in honor of its benefactor. Its origin occurs with the establishment of a congregation of Nahua Indians of San José de Huejúcar, which means "place of willows." Temple of San Antonio de Padua The temple of San Antonio is a monument and religious masterpiece, located in the historic center of the City of Aguascalientes, in the state of the same name, designed and built by the self-taught practical architect Refugio Reyes Rivas. Its construction began in 1895 and the work was completed in 1908.
